contents.text: Azure Cloud Services is a collection of integrated cloud services that developers and IT professionals use to build, deploy, and manage applications through Microsoft's global network of data centers.
Azure Cloud Services include services such as virtual machines, app services, storage, databases, networking, and more.
Azure Virtual Machines allow users to create and manage virtual machines in the cloud, providing flexibility and scalability for various workloads.
Azure App Services enable developers to build, deploy, and scale web apps and APIs quickly without managing the underlying infrastructure.
Azure Storage offers scalable and secure cloud storage solutions for data storage, backup, and disaster recovery.
Azure SQL Database is a fully managed relational database service that provides high availability, security, and performance for applications.
Azure Networking services provide virtual networks, load balancers, VPN gateways, and other networking capabilities to connect cloud resources securely.
Step 1: Go to the Azure website
Step 2: Click on 'Start free' or 'Sign in' to create an account
Step 3: Fill in the required information such as email, password, and country
Step 4: Verify your email address to activate your account
Step 5: Once verified, sign in to your Azure account
Step 6: Navigate to the Azure portal to start using Azure services
Azure Portal is a web-based application that allows users to access and manage Azure resources.
Users can create, manage, and monitor their Azure services and resources through the Azure Portal.
Azure Portal provides a graphical interface for managing Azure resources, making it easy for users to navigate and perform tasks.
Users can customize their Azure Portal dashboard to display relevant information and resources based on their preferences.
Azure Portal supports role-based access control, allowing users to assign permissions and control access to resources.
Azure Portal offers a wide range of tools and services for monitoring, analyzing, and optimizing Azure resources.
Azure Resource Groups are logical containers that help manage and organize Azure resources.
contents.codeSnippet: az group create --name MyResourceGroup --location eastus

contents.text: Resource Groups can contain resources such as virtual machines, databases, web apps, storage accounts, and more.
contents.codeSnippet: az vm create --resource-group MyResourceGroup --name MyVM --image UbuntuLTS

contents.text: Resource Groups provide a way to manage access control, policies, and tags for related Azure resources.
contents.codeSnippet: az group update --name MyResourceGroup --set tags.Environment=Production

contents.text: Introduction to Azure Virtual Machines
Creating an Azure Virtual Machine
contents.codeSnippet: az vm create --resource-group MyResourceGroup --name MyVM --image UbuntuLTS --admin-username azureuser --generate-ssh-keys

contents.text: Connecting to an Azure Virtual Machine
contents.codeSnippet: ssh azureuser@<Public-IP-Address>

contents.text: Resizing an Azure Virtual Machine
contents.codeSnippet: az vm resize --resource-group MyResourceGroup --name MyVM --size Standard_DS2_v2

contents.text: Managing Azure Virtual Machine Extensions
contents.codeSnippet: az vm extension set --resource-group MyResourceGroup --vm-name MyVM --name VMAccessForLinux --publisher Microsoft.OSTCExtensions --version 1.4 --settings '{"username":"azureuser", "ssh_key":"<SSH-Public-Key>"}'

contents.text: Creating a Virtual Machine Scale Set in Azure
contents.codeSnippet: az vmss create --resource-group MyResourceGroup --name MyScaleSet --image UbuntuLTS --upgrade-policy-mode automatic --admin-username azureuser --generate-ssh-keys

contents.text: Introduction to Azure Storage Accounts
Types of Azure Storage Accounts (Blob, File, Queue, Table)
Creating an Azure Storage Account using Azure Portal
contents.codeSnippet: az storage account create --name <account-name> --resource-group <resource-group-name> --location <location> --sku Standard_LRS

contents.text: Access Keys and Connection Strings in Azure Storage Accounts
Managing Azure Storage Account Keys
contents.codeSnippet: az storage account keys list --account-name <account-name> --resource-group <resource-group-name>

contents.text: Setting up CORS rules for Azure Storage Accounts
Using Shared Access Signatures (SAS) with Azure Storage Accounts
Monitoring and Logging for Azure Storage Accounts
Azure App Service is a fully managed platform for building, deploying, and scaling web apps and APIs.
contents.codeSnippet: az webapp create --name <app-name> --resource-group <resource-group-name> --plan <app-service-plan-name> --runtime <runtime>

contents.text: Azure App Service supports multiple programming languages including .NET, Java, Node.js, PHP, Python, and Ruby.
contents.codeSnippet: az webapp deployment source config --name <app-name> --resource-group <resource-group-name> --repo-url <git-repo-url> --branch <branch-name>

contents.text: Azure App Service provides built-in CI/CD integration with Azure DevOps, GitHub, Bitbucket, and other Git repositories.
contents.codeSnippet: az webapp log tail --name <app-name> --resource-group <resource-group-name>

contents.text: Azure App Service offers auto-scaling and load balancing capabilities to handle varying traffic loads.
contents.codeSnippet: az webapp config appsettings set --name <app-name> --resource-group <resource-group-name> --settings <key-value-pairs>

contents.text: Azure App Service allows for easy integration with Azure SQL Database, Azure Cosmos DB, and other Azure services.
contents.codeSnippet: az webapp config connection-string set --name <app-name> --resource-group <resource-group-name> --connection-string-type SQLAzure --settings <key-value-pairs>

contents.text: Azure Functions is a serverless compute service that lets you run event-triggered code without having to explicitly provision or manage infrastructure.
Azure Functions can be used to execute code in response to various events like HTTP requests, timers, queues, blobs, and more.
Azure Functions supports multiple programming languages including C#, JavaScript, Python, and PowerShell.
Azure Functions can be easily integrated with other Azure services like Azure Storage, Azure Cosmos DB, Azure Service Bus, and more.
Azure Functions can be deployed and managed directly from the Azure portal, Visual Studio, or using Azure CLI and Azure DevOps.
Azure Functions pricing is based on the number of executions and resource consumption, offering a pay-as-you-go model for cost efficiency.
Introduction to Azure Security Center
Key features of Azure Security Center
How to enable Azure Security Center
Azure Security Center pricing and plans
Using Azure Security Center for threat detection and response
Integrating Azure Security Center with Azure Sentinel
Best practices for configuring Azure Security Center policies
Introduction to Azure Key Vault
Benefits of using Azure Key Vault
Creating an Azure Key Vault
contents.codeSnippet: az keyvault create --name MyKeyVault --resource-group MyResourceGroup --location eastus

contents.text: Adding a secret to Azure Key Vault
contents.codeSnippet: az keyvault secret set --vault-name MyKeyVault --name MySecret --value MySecretValue

contents.text: Retrieving a secret from Azure Key Vault
contents.codeSnippet: az keyvault secret show --vault-name MyKeyVault --name MySecret

contents.text: Using Azure Key Vault in an Azure Function
contents.codeSnippet: var secretValue = await new KeyVaultClient().GetSecretAsync("https://MyKeyVault.vault.azure.net/", "MySecret");

contents.text: Best practices for managing secrets in Azure Key Vault
Introduction to Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS)
Creating an AKS Cluster in Azure Portal
contents.codeSnippet: az aks create --resource-group myResourceGroup --name myAKSCluster --node-count 1 --enable-addons monitoring --generate-ssh-keys

contents.text: Scaling an AKS Cluster
contents.codeSnippet: az aks scale --resource-group myResourceGroup --name myAKSCluster --node-count 3

contents.text: Deploying an Application to AKS
contents.codeSnippet: kubectl apply -f myApp.yaml

contents.text: Updating an Application in AKS
contents.codeSnippet: kubectl apply -f myUpdatedApp.yaml

contents.text: Monitoring AKS Cluster with Azure Monitor
contents.codeSnippet: az aks enable-addons --resource-group myResourceGroup --name myAKSCluster --addons monitoring

contents.text: Scaling AKS Cluster with Virtual Nodes
contents.codeSnippet: az aks create --resource-group myResourceGroup --name myAKSCluster --node-count 1 --enable-addons virtual-node --enable-virtual-nodes --generate-ssh-keys

contents.text: Azure Monitor is a service in Azure that provides a comprehensive solution for collecting, analyzing, and acting on telemetry data from your cloud and on-premises environments.
Azure Monitor helps you maximize the performance and availability of your applications and proactively identify issues before they impact users.
Azure Monitor includes features like metrics, logs, alerts, and dashboards to monitor the health of your resources and applications.
Metrics in Azure Monitor provide a way to monitor the performance of your resources by collecting data at regular intervals.
Logs in Azure Monitor allow you to collect and analyze log and performance data from various sources, including Azure resources, applications, and operating systems.
Alerts in Azure Monitor enable you to set up notifications based on metrics or logs to proactively respond to issues in your environment.
Dashboards in Azure Monitor provide customizable views of your monitoring data, allowing you to visualize and analyze the health and performance of your resources.
Azure Logic Apps is a cloud service that helps you automate and orchestrate tasks, business processes, and workflows.
contents.codeSnippet: Create a simple Logic App that triggers when a new email arrives in a mailbox and sends a notification to a Teams channel.

contents.text: Logic Apps provide a visual designer to model and automate your workflows without writing code.
contents.codeSnippet: Define a workflow in the Logic Apps designer that integrates data from a SQL database with a Salesforce account.

contents.text: Azure Logic Apps offer a wide range of connectors to interact with various services and applications.
contents.codeSnippet: Use the Azure Blob Storage connector to create a Logic App that monitors a storage account for new files and triggers an action.

contents.text: Logic Apps support triggers and actions to define the flow of your workflows.
contents.codeSnippet: Implement a Logic App trigger that starts a workflow when a new item is added to a SharePoint list.

contents.text: Azure Cosmos DB is a globally distributed, multi-model database service provided by Microsoft Azure.
It offers high availability, low latency, and scalability for your applications.
Azure Cosmos DB supports multiple data models such as document, key-value, graph, and column-family.
You can use Azure Cosmos DB to store and access data with various APIs like SQL, MongoDB, Gremlin, Cassandra, and Table.
To create a new Azure Cosmos DB account, you can use the Azure portal or Azure CLI.
Here is an example of creating a new Azure Cosmos DB account using Azure CLI:
contents.codeSnippet: az cosmosdb create --name MyCosmosDBAccount --resource-group MyResourceGroup --kind GlobalDocumentDB --locations "East US=0" "West US=1"

contents.text: Azure Cosmos DB offers comprehensive SLAs for throughput, latency, consistency, and availability.
You can scale your Azure Cosmos DB database throughput and storage independently based on your application needs.
Azure Cosmos DB provides automatic and manual indexing options to optimize query performance.
You can integrate Azure Cosmos DB with other Azure services like Azure Functions, Azure Logic Apps, and Azure Stream Analytics.
Introduction to Azure Machine Learning
Setting up an Azure Machine Learning workspace
contents.codeSnippet:
from azureml.core import Workspace

# Load the workspace from the saved config file
ws = Workspace.from_config()

contents.text: Creating and running an Azure Machine Learning experiment
contents.codeSnippet:
from azureml.core import Experiment

# Create an experiment
experiment = Experiment(workspace=ws, name='my-experiment')

# Start the experiment
run = experiment.start_logging()

contents.text: Training a machine learning model in Azure
contents.codeSnippet:
from azureml.core import Dataset
from azureml.train.sklearn import SKLearn

# Get the training dataset
dataset = Dataset.get_by_name(ws, name='training_data')

# Define the training script
script_params = {
    '--regularization': 0.1
}

# Create an estimator
estimator = SKLearn(source_directory='.',
                    entry_script='train.py',
                    script_params=script_params,
                    compute_target='local')

# Train the model
run = experiment.submit(estimator)

contents.text: Deploying a trained model as a web service in Azure
contents.codeSnippet:
from azureml.core import Model
from azureml.core.webservice import AciWebservice, Webservice

# Register the model
model = Model.register(workspace=ws, model_path='model.pkl', model_name='my-model')

# Deploy the model as a web service
service = Model.deploy(workspace=ws, name='my-service', models=[model], inference_config=inference_config, deployment_config=aciconfig)

service.wait_for_deployment(show_output=True)

contents.text: Azure Cognitive Services is a set of APIs and services provided by Microsoft Azure that enables developers to add intelligent features to their applications without needing in-depth data science or machine learning expertise.
Some of the key services offered by Azure Cognitive Services include Computer Vision, Face API, Text Analytics, Speech Services, and Language Understanding (LUIS).

Computer Vision service in Azure Cognitive Services allows developers to analyze and extract information from images and videos, enabling tasks such as object detection, image moderation, and optical character recognition (OCR).
contents.codeSnippet: var computerVisionClient = new ComputerVisionClient(new ApiKeyServiceClientCredentials(apiKey))

contents.text: Face API in Azure Cognitive Services provides facial recognition capabilities, allowing developers to detect and identify faces in images, as well as analyze facial attributes like age, gender, and emotion.
contents.codeSnippet: var faceClient = new FaceClient(new ApiKeyServiceClientCredentials(apiKey))

contents.text: Text Analytics service in Azure Cognitive Services enables sentiment analysis, key phrase extraction, and language detection from text data, helping developers gain insights from unstructured text.
contents.codeSnippet: var textAnalyticsClient = new TextAnalyticsClient(new ApiKeyServiceClientCredentials(apiKey))

contents.text: Speech Services in Azure Cognitive Services offer speech-to-text and text-to-speech capabilities, allowing developers to transcribe audio files, convert text to speech, and customize speech models for specific use cases.
contents.codeSnippet: var speechConfig = SpeechConfig.FromSubscription(subscriptionKey, serviceRegion)

contents.text: Azure IoT Hub is a fully managed service that enables reliable and secure bidirectional communication between IoT devices and the cloud.
Azure IoT Hub provides device-to-cloud and cloud-to-device messaging over MQTT, AMQP, and HTTP protocols.
Azure IoT Hub supports device management, including device provisioning, configuration, and monitoring.
Azure IoT Hub offers robust security features such as device authentication, access control, and data encryption.
Azure IoT Hub integrates seamlessly with other Azure services like Azure Functions, Azure Stream Analytics, and Azure Storage.
To create an IoT Hub in Azure, you can use the Azure portal, Azure CLI, Azure PowerShell, or Azure Resource Manager templates.
Azure IoT Hub SDKs are available for various programming languages including C, Java, Node.js, and Python.
Introduction to Azure Databricks
Key features of Azure Databricks
Creating an Azure Databricks workspace
Running jobs in Azure Databricks
Integrating Azure Databricks with other Azure services
Azure Data Lake is a cloud-based storage and analytics service provided by Microsoft Azure.
Azure Data Lake Store is a scalable and secure data repository that allows you to store and analyze large amounts of data.
Azure Data Lake Analytics is a distributed analytics service that allows you to run big data analytics and processing frameworks on data stored in Azure Data Lake Store.
Azure Data Lake supports various data formats such as CSV, JSON, Parquet, and Avro.
You can use Azure Data Lake tools like Azure Data Lake Storage Explorer and Azure Data Lake Analytics Tools to interact with and analyze data in Azure Data Lake.
Introduction to Azure Event Hubs
Key features of Azure Event Hubs
Creating an Azure Event Hub namespace
contents.codeSnippet: az eventhubs namespace create --name MyNamespace --resource-group MyResourceGroup --location eastus

contents.text: Creating an Azure Event Hub within a namespace
contents.codeSnippet: az eventhubs eventhub create --name MyEventHub --namespace-name MyNamespace --resource-group MyResourceGroup

contents.text: Sending events to an Azure Event Hub
contents.codeSnippet: az eventhubs eventhub send --hub-name MyEventHub --namespace-name MyNamespace --message "Hello, Azure Event Hubs!"

contents.text: Receiving events from an Azure Event Hub
contents.codeSnippet: az eventhubs eventhub receive --hub-name MyEventHub --namespace-name MyNamespace

contents.text: Scaling Azure Event Hubs
Introduction to Azure Data Factory
Key features of Azure Data Factory
Creating a pipeline in Azure Data Factory
contents.codeSnippet: Create a pipeline using Azure portal or ARM templates.

contents.text: Data movement and transformation in Azure Data Factory
contents.codeSnippet: Use copy activity for data movement and data flow activity for transformation.

contents.text: Integration with other Azure services in Azure Data Factory
contents.codeSnippet: Integrate with Azure Blob Storage, Azure SQL Database, Azure Data Lake Storage, etc.

contents.text: Monitoring and managing pipelines in Azure Data Factory
contents.codeSnippet: Monitor pipeline runs, manage triggers, and set up alerts for monitoring.

contents.text: Introduction to Azure Synapse Analytics
Key features of Azure Synapse Analytics
Creating a Synapse Workspace in Azure Portal
Running SQL queries in Azure Synapse Analytics
contents.codeSnippet: SELECT * FROM TableName;

contents.text: Integrating Azure Synapse Analytics with Azure Data Lake Storage
Using Azure Synapse Analytics for big data processing
Azure Blob Storage is a cloud storage service provided by Microsoft Azure for storing large amounts of unstructured data like text or binary data.
Azure Blob Storage allows you to store and access your data from anywhere in the world over HTTP or HTTPS.
Azure Blob Storage offers three types of blobs: block blobs, append blobs, and page blobs.
Block blobs are optimized for streaming and storing cloud objects, like documents, media files, backups, etc.
Append blobs are designed for append operations, making them ideal for scenarios like logging data.
Page blobs are optimized for random read/write operations and are commonly used for VHD files associated with Azure Virtual Machines.
You can interact with Azure Blob Storage using various SDKs, REST APIs, or Azure CLI commands.
To upload a file to Azure Blob Storage using the Azure Storage SDK for Python, you can use the following code snippet:
contents.codeSnippet:
from azure.storage.blob import BlobServiceClient

connect_str = "<your_connection_string>"
blob_service_client = BlobServiceClient.from_connection_string(connect_str)
blob_client = blob_service_client.get_blob_client(container="<container_name>", blob="<blob_name>")
blob_client.upload_blob(data=<file_data>)

contents.text: To list all blobs in a container using Azure CLI, you can run the following command:
contents.codeSnippet: az storage blob list --account-name <storage_account_name> --container-name <container_name> --output table

contents.text: Azure Blob Storage provides features like lifecycle management, versioning, and encryption to help you manage and secure your data effectively.
Azure CDN is a content delivery network service provided by Microsoft Azure.
Azure CDN accelerates the delivery of web content to users by caching content at strategically placed physical nodes across the globe.
Azure CDN offers various features such as dynamic site acceleration, video on demand streaming, and secure delivery of content.
Azure CDN integrates seamlessly with other Azure services like Azure Blob Storage, Azure Web Apps, and Azure Media Services.
To use Azure CDN, you need to create a CDN profile and endpoint in the Azure portal.
Here is an example of creating a CDN profile using Azure CLI:
contents.codeSnippet: az cdn profile create --name MyCDNProfile --resource-group MyResourceGroup --sku Standard_Akamai

contents.text: After creating a CDN profile, you can create an endpoint to start delivering content through Azure CDN.
contents.codeSnippet: az cdn endpoint create --profile-name MyCDNProfile --name MyCDNEndpoint --origin www.example.com

contents.text: Azure CDN provides analytics and monitoring tools to track CDN usage, performance, and bandwidth consumption.
Introduction to Azure API Management
Key Features of Azure API Management
Creating an API in Azure API Management
Securing APIs in Azure API Management
API Versioning in Azure API Management
Monitoring and Analytics in Azure API Management
Azure Backup is a cloud-based service that provides backup and restore capabilities for Azure virtual machines, on-premises servers, and workloads.
Azure Backup allows you to schedule backups, retain backups for a specified period, and perform on-demand backups.
Azure Backup integrates with Azure Virtual Machines, Azure Blob Storage, and Azure Files for storing backup data.
Azure Backup offers features like backup encryption, backup monitoring, and backup alerts to ensure data protection and compliance.
To configure Azure Backup, you need to create a Recovery Services vault in the Azure portal and register the resources you want to back up.
Azure Backup supports both file and folder backup as well as application-consistent backup for supported applications.
You can use Azure Backup to restore individual files, folders, applications, or entire virtual machines to a specific point in time.
Azure Backup provides options for long-term retention, allowing you to store backups for extended periods based on your retention policies.
Azure Site Recovery (ASR) is a disaster recovery solution from Microsoft Azure that enables businesses to protect and recover their workloads in the event of a disaster.
ASR replicates workloads running on physical and virtual machines (VMs) from a primary site to a secondary location, such as Azure or a secondary data center.
ASR provides continuous replication of workloads, ensuring minimal data loss and downtime in case of a disaster.
ASR supports various replication scenarios, including Azure to Azure, on-premises to Azure, and cross-region replication.
ASR offers automated failover and failback capabilities, allowing businesses to quickly switch to their secondary site during an outage and then revert back when the primary site is restored.
ASR integrates with other Azure services like Azure Backup and Azure Monitor to provide a comprehensive disaster recovery solution.
Introduction to Azure Traffic Manager
Key features of Azure Traffic Manager
Creating a Traffic Manager profile in Azure Portal
Configuring endpoints in Azure Traffic Manager
Traffic routing methods in Azure Traffic Manager
Monitoring and troubleshooting Azure Traffic Manager
Introduction to Azure Cost Management
Understanding Azure Cost Management features and benefits
Setting up Azure Cost Management for your subscription
Viewing and analyzing cost data in Azure Cost Management
Creating budgets and alerts in Azure Cost Management
Optimizing costs using recommendations from Azure Cost Management
Integrating Azure Cost Management with Azure DevOps for cost control
Azure Governance is the set of policies, procedures, and processes implemented to manage and control an organization's Azure resources.
Azure Policy is a service in Azure that allows you to create, assign, and manage policies to enforce rules and effects on your Azure resources.
contents.codeSnippet: az policy assignment create --name 'myAssignment' --policy 'myPolicyDefinition' --scope '/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}'

contents.text: Azure Blueprints enable you to define a repeatable set of Azure resources that adhere to organizational standards and requirements.
contents.codeSnippet: az blueprint create --name 'myBlueprint' --subscription '{subscriptionId}' --resource-group 'myResourceGroup'

contents.text: Azure Resource Manager (ARM) templates are JSON files that define the resources and configurations needed for an Azure solution.
Azure RBAC (Role-Based Access Control) allows you to manage access to Azure resources by assigning roles to users, groups, or services.
contents.codeSnippet: az role assignment create --assignee '{principalId}' --role 'Contributor' --scope '/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}'

contents.text: Azure Identity is a service that helps you manage and secure access to your Azure resources.
Azure Identity provides features such as Azure Active Directory, Azure AD B2C, and Azure AD Domain Services.
Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) is Microsoft's cloud-based identity and access management service.
Azure AD B2C is a service that allows you to customize and control how customers sign up, sign in, and manage their profiles when using your applications.
Azure AD Domain Services provides managed domain services such as domain join, group policy, LDAP, and Kerberos authentication.
To authenticate users and grant access to Azure resources, you can use Azure AD authentication.
Azure Identity helps you implement secure authentication and authorization mechanisms for your applications running on Azure.
Azure Architecture refers to the design and structure of applications and services deployed on the Microsoft Azure cloud platform.
Azure Architecture involves designing scalable, reliable, and secure solutions that leverage Azure's various services such as Virtual Machines, Azure Functions, Azure Storage, and Azure SQL Database.

Azure Architecture typically follows best practices like using Azure Resource Manager (ARM) templates for infrastructure as code, implementing high availability and disaster recovery strategies, and optimizing cost management.

Azure Architecture can be categorized into different layers such as the presentation layer, application layer, data layer, and infrastructure layer, each serving a specific purpose in the overall solution.

Azure Architecture design considerations include factors like performance, scalability, security, compliance, and monitoring, ensuring that the solution meets the requirements of the business and end-users.
Azure offers various certification paths for individuals to demonstrate their expertise in different Azure services and technologies.
Some of the popular Azure certification paths include Azure Administrator, Azure Developer, Azure Solutions Architect, Azure AI Engineer, Azure Data Engineer, and Azure Security Engineer.
Each certification path consists of different exams that test the candidate's knowledge and skills in specific Azure domains.
For example, the Azure Administrator certification path includes exams like AZ-104: Microsoft Azure Administrator and AZ-303: Microsoft Azure Architect Technologies.
Candidates can choose the certification path that aligns with their career goals and interests in Azure.

Key components of Azure Cloud Adoption Framework
Benefits of using Azure Cloud Adoption Framework
Best practices for implementing Azure Cloud Adoption Framework
Case studies of successful Azure Cloud Adoption Framework implementations
Use Resource Groups to logically group resources in Azure for better management and organization.
Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to control access to Azure resources based on specific roles and responsibilities.
Utilize Azure Policy to enforce organizational standards and compliance requirements across Azure resources.
Implement Azure Monitor to gain insights into the performance and health of Azure resources in real-time.
Leverage Azure Security Center to strengthen the security posture of Azure resources and detect potential threats.
Implement Azure Backup to protect critical data and applications by creating backup copies in Azure.
Utilize Azure Cost Management + Billing to monitor and optimize Azure spending and resource utilization.
Implement Azure DevOps for seamless collaboration, continuous integration, and continuous delivery of applications on Azure.
Utilize Azure Resource Manager templates to automate the deployment and management of Azure resources.
Implement Azure Availability Zones to ensure high availability and resiliency of applications by distributing them across multiple data centers within a region.
